i < 10; i++ )        {            tweet twt = new tweet();            twt.setTitle("A nice header for Tweet # " +i);            twt.setBody("Some random body text for the tweet # " +i);            tweets.add(twt); this adds items to the action bar if it is present.        getMenuInflater().inflate(R.menu.menu_tweetlistactivity, menu);        return true;    }    @Override    public boolean onOptionsItemSelected(MenuItem item) {        // Handle action bar item clicks here. Please using this api: String.getBytes.
Answer:


*

*String.getBytes() returns a byte array.

*FileOutputStream.write(byte[]) writes the given byte array to the file.

*FileOutputStream.close() closes the file.


Explanation:


*

*String.getBytes() returns a byte array that contains the bytes of the string.

*FileOutputStream.write(byte[]) writes the given byte array to the file.

*FileOutputStream.close() closes the file.


Code:
String FILENAME = "hello_file";
String string = "hello world!";
FileOutputStream fos = Context.openFileOutput(FILENAME,MODE_PRIVATE);
fos.write(string.getBytes());
fos.close();

Explanation:


*

*String FILENAME = "hello_file"; creates a string variable called FILENAME and assigns it the value "hello_file".

*String string = "hello world!"; creates a string variable called string and assigns it the value "hello world!".

*FileOutputStream fos = Context.openFileOutput(FILENAME,MODE_PRIVATE); creates a FileOutputStream object called fos and calls the openFileOutput() method on the Context object to open a file with the name "hello_file" in the private mode.

*fos.write(string.getBytes()); calls the write() method on the FileOutputStream object to write the bytes of the string to the file.

*fos.close(); calls the close() method on the FileOutputStream object to close the file.
